meanings.definition: To form into a new group or groups after a disbandment.
meanings.sent1: After the game, the children decided to regroup and play again.
meanings.sent2: During the mission, the soldiers had to regroup to plan their next move.
meanings.sent3: The toys seemed to regroup on their own, forming a neat line on the shelf.
meanings.sent4: The students quickly regrouped, forming study groups for the upcoming exam.
meanings.sent5: As the storm passed, the birds regrouped in the trees, chirping happily.

meanings.definition: To reorganize or rearrange in order to prepare for further action.
meanings.sent1: The team needed to regroup their strategy before the final match.
meanings.sent2: After the meeting, the employees had to regroup their tasks for the project.
meanings.sent3: The ants had to regroup their food supplies after the unexpected rain.
meanings.sent4: She had to regroup her thoughts before making an important decision.
meanings.sent5: The dancers had to regroup their formations for the upcoming performance.
